oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mt. Lebanon Baptist: front and side view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of church front and side view. Church is a brick, gable-fronted structure with columns. Facade of church contains double doors, light features flanking the entranceway, a cornerstone, and a gable vent. Church's exterior is composed of three sections: gable-fronted vestibule with one side sash window, gable-fronted main section with four sash windows on the side, and a shed-roofed rear. Sidewalk surrounds the exterior of the church.

Mt. Lebanon Baptist Church has Reconstruction era roots, dating back to its construction in 1869. The original frame building was replaced with a brick structure in 1954. At the time of documentation (May 15, 1998), the church was situated within a black neighborhood south of downtown Camden. Larry C. Jackson served as pastor at that time and the church.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
gable roofs; double doors
